author: Mike Kelly
title: Theresa May as Prime Minister - what are her plans for the North East
text:
Unions and business bosses unite in giving new Prime Minister Theresa May a cautious welcome Shares Get daily news by email PA Wire Prime Minister David Cameron speaks during his last Prime Minister's Questions, flanked by Theresa May, in the House of Commons, London 
New Prime Minister Theresa May has received a cautious welcome from union bosses as well as the business community in the North East. 
They hope her arrival will mean stability after a period of uncertainty as well as a change of tack on austerity. 
In her leadership campaign Mrs May said she’d ditch Chancellor George Osborne’s plan to produce a budget surplus by 2020. 
She explained: “While it is absolutely vital that the government continues with its intention to reduce public spending and cut the budget deficit, we should no longer seek to reach a budget surplus by the end of the parliament.” 
This would mark a slight easing of austerity rather than doing away with it. 
However in a surprise move Mrs May pledged an overhaul of corporate governance, including appointing employee representatives to boards to keep control on excessive executive pay. In doing so, she marked a radical departure from the policies of the UK’s last female prime minister, Margaret Thatcher. 
The unions have welcomed her comments. Beth Farhat - Regional Secretary TUC 
Beth Farhat, regional secretary of the Northern TUC, said: “Theresa May has said she will change corporate governance to crack down on excess executive pay, put workers on company boards and tighten up rules to block predatory takeovers. 
“And she has said we need a more active industrial policy to protect British industry. 
“These are things that the TUC has long campaigned for, so if the implementation is done well it could be good for the North East. 
“It could help ensure companies in our regional industries are focussed on long term, sustainable growth and have fairer wage policies.” 
She added: “But the North East’s prospects also depend a great deal on her handling of Brexit. The TUC has published a plan of action for the steps the government needs to take to prevent the Brexit vote becoming an economic calamity. 
“She should immediately be making plans to step up public investment across the UK. We need public investment in the North East to improve our infrastructure, keep the economy growing, and ensure private investors see a strong future here.” Jonathan Walker (right) at the North East England Tourism Awards 
Meanwhile Jonathan Walker, head of policy and campaigns, North East England Chamber of Commerce , said: “We now urge her to provide reassurance for businesses concerned about the impact of the EU Referendum result and show commitment to support our region’s exporters. 
“We will continue to campaign for a fair funding deal for the region and the need for decisions on major capital projects like Heathrow’s expansion which have been on the backburner for far too long.” North East Chair of the Institute of Directors and Senior Partner at Recognition PR Graham Robb 
His views were echoed by Graham Robb, chairman of the Institute of Directors in the North, who said: “I have met Mrs May a number times. She stood for election in the North East in the 1990s and understands the issues we deal with every day and how the region’s uniquely strong work ethic and entrepreneurial spirit will overcome them.”
